Snorkels

Some of the Dutch submarines that we captured use a curious device called by them a sniffer. It's a pipe system that allows them to use diesel engines while staying at periscope depth. As the danger from allied aircrafts increases with each passing month and surface of the seas becomes too dangerous to operate for the u-boats, this technology may prove to be vital. Our submarines wouldn't have too surface that often. We are already working on the adaptation of this technology to our u-boats, but advice from experienced officer serving on the u-boat would help to develop it much faster.
Anti-Radar Coating for Snorkels

It's possible that enemy radars may be able to detect retracted snorkels, when the boat is submerged. There are some ways to counter that, by coating our snorkels with materials that disperse radar waves.
"Metox" Radar Detector (T1)

After Rommel's troops captured British Wellington aircraft in North Africa, its radar technology was a subject of our ongoing ?investigation.

Metox & Grandin company in Paris is working on a device that would be able to detect these radars from large distances and give our u-boats early warning. Our u-boats would be much safer from air patrols with this technology as they would simply submerge long before aircrafts would arrive at their location.

While there are already working prototypes of such detector, a help from experienced officer would speed up its practical integration on our u-boats.
"Borkum" Radar Detector (T2)

There are growing reports of surprise aircraft attacks despite careful use of ?Metox” radar detector. Interrogations give us a clue that enemy may have a technology to detect ?Metox” radar detectors themselves from much larger range than is normally possible. Our tests indeed suggest that this detector creates some own emissions, so this is possible.

Our military researchers already work on a new radar detector, codenamed "Borkum", that would be free of such emissions and would have a bit better spectrum coverage. Sadly, there are still multiple technical obstacles to pass. Help of experienced radio technician would definitely help.
"Naxos" Radar Detector (T3)

Whilst examining the wreckage of an RAF Short Stirling that was shot down by Luftwaffe over Rotterdam we discovered that Allies started to use radar technology operating at 10 cm frequency. It's a major technological breakthrough and our current radar detector designs aren't capable of detecting them.

Our response to this finding is a new radar detector device called ?Naxos”. It would theoretically be able to detect all radars operating at 8 to 12 cm frequencies.
"Tunis" Radar Detector (T4)

Considering that enemy was often a few steps ahead of us in radar technology, this time, we should take the initiative and create a radar detector that would be able to detect radars operating on frequencies as small as 3 cm.

Our researchers claim that this advancement would also allow to greatly increase effective range of our new radar detector.

Improved Toilets

While our u-boats are impressively capable of staying at large depths for a long time, there is one nagging issue that often leads our crews to irrationally move out of the safe depth. This issue is our current toilet design as it's functional only at a small depth. There are many ways to address this issue, but it was neglected so far. Presence of a veteran officer that would explain the weight of this improvement would help to allocate more resources for developing better hydraulic systems that would work on a greater depth.
Hydrophone: KDB (T1)

While our current GHG hydrophones are very effective and outmatch enemy technologies, they don't ensure full direction coverage for listening.

A group of engineers created a simple prototype device, that carries a set of microphones, able to rotate around one axis. It seems be a very promising project, but still needs work before being integrated on our u-boats.
Hydrophone: GHG-Balkon (T2)

A group of our engineers suggested that our current GHG design may be improved by mounting the microphones on a dome attached to the bottom part of the hull. This solution would increase direction coverage of GHG microphones and as addition the extra space in dome would be able to hold more microphones, increasing precision of the whole system.

Improved torpedo pistols

Our current pistol design turned out to be faulty and we must prioritize fixing it above other things. Pistols with magnetic (MZ) setting often tend to explode on their own before reaching the target, while impact (AZ) setting works correctly only close to the right angle.

There are many theories why things are this way and different branches shift responsibility to one another. Presence of experienced engineer from one of our u-boats would help to move things forward and potentially find some solutions.
G7e Torpedo (T3)

Our current G7e T2 electric torpedoes have some technical limitations that noticeably limit their use like a low range, speed and despite our earlier efforts there are still many pistol issues left, especially with the magnetic (MZ) setting.

Our engineers already work on improved design - G7e T3. These torpedoes at current prototype stages bear a promise to fix all aforementioned issues of T2 torpedoes.
Torpedo control program - FAT

A novel idea appeared to enhance our existing torpedo designs with a control mechanism that would steer the torpedo to follow a specific pattern in case of a miss. The proposed pattern would increase the probability of scoring a hit, if torpedo would be fired inside a convoy.
Torpedo control program - LUT

We consider our FAT torpedo programs to be a great success, although it's time to upgrade it further. The main drawback of FAT program is that it assumes a very specific firing angle for the u-boat for optimal run.

There is a new idea of upgrading it with additional setting that would make the pattern independent from the initial firing angle.
G7es "Zaunk?nig" Torpedo (T5)

Our engineers are designing a new type of torpedo - T5. These new torpedoes are acoustically homing at nearby targets, turning many missed shots into perfect hits. It's a complicated design though and experienced engineer would definitely be helpful in addressing its remaining issues.
